WRITING.TITLE: Thousand Sons semi-competitive army list ideas
WRITING.TEXT: I just recently started to get into thousand sons and need some opinions on list building. I play against mainly Grey Knights and a combo of deathwatch/ultramarines (Guilliman and tactical marines). I #8217;m perfectly fine playing a unit I like even if it #8217;s not the most competitive. So far I only have Magnus and 3 squads of Rubric marines (unassembled). My most recent plan is something like this: Battalion Detachment (+3 cp) HQ - Ahriman on disc of Tzeentch (166) Exalted Sorcerer on disc of Tzeentch w/ Dark Matter Crystal(141) Troops - Rubric Marines - Aspiring Sorcerer, Inferno Boltgun x 8, Soulreaper Cannon (220) Rubric Marines - Aspiring Sorcerer, Inferno Boltgun x 8, Soulreaper Cannon (220) Rubric Marines - Aspiring Sorcerer, Inferno Boltgun x4 (107) Elites - Scarab Occult Terminators - Scarab Occult Sorcerer, Inferno Combi-Bolter x 8, Hellfyre Missile Rack, Soulreaper Cannon (438) Heavy Support - Predator - Twin Lascannon, Lascannon x2 (190) Dedicated Transport - Rhino (72) Super-Heavy Auxiliary Detachment Lord of War - Magnus the Red (445) - Warlord Basically one 10 man squad of Rubricae will come in from the warp and the other will ride around in the Rhino. Everyone else just supports each other and smites the life out of all my enemies and the predator is there to deal with any vehicles basically. I dont love Tzaangors but I #8217;m open to them. I #8217;d like to keep it strictly Thousand Sons for now and stay away from Daemons until I get competitive with the list. Basically my questions are -Will this list hold its own most of the time? -Are rhinos worth it? -Are Daemon Princes better than Exalted Sorcerers? -Are Helbrutes worth it? -Should I spend that many points on Termies? -Should I delve into Forgeworld? is this too assholeish? Literally any advice is appreciated. Thanks a lot.

So basically despite how much I might hate it, to be competitive at all I have to use Tzaangors and the such. I #8217;m curious tho, should I go ahead and buy the Battlefirce Tzeentch Arcanites Changecult and just convert the Acolytes to Tzaangors? I can #8217;t find an actually box of Tzaangors anywhere. Anyways, how does this new list look? Also will it fair decently against elite armies? **++ Battalion Detachment +3CP (Chaos - Thousand Sons) [66 PL, 1174pts] ++** **+ HQ +** **Ahriman on Disc of Tzeentch [9 PL, 166pts]:** **Daemon Prince of Tzeentch [9 PL, 180pts]:** Hellforged sword, Helm of the Third Eye, Wings **+ Troops +** **Rubric Marines [27 PL, 433pts]** . **Aspiring Sorcerer:** Force stave, Inferno Bolt Pistol . **17x Rubric Marine w/ Inferno Boltgun:** 17x Inferno boltgun . **Rubric Marine w/ Soulreaper cannon:** Soulreaper cannon . **Rubric Marine w/ Soulreaper cannon:** Soulreaper cannon **Tzaangors [7 PL, 150pts]:** Brayhorn, 19x Tzaangor w/ Tzaangor Blades . **Twistbray:** Tzaangor blades **Tzaangors [4 PL, 70pts]:** 9x Tzaangor w/ Tzaangor Blades . **Twistbray:** Tzaangor blades **+ Elites +** **Tzaangor Shaman [5 PL, 90pts]:** Dark Matter Crystal, Force stave **+ Fast Attack +** **Tzaangor Enlightened [5 PL, 85pts]:** Aviarch, 4x Enlightened, Fatecaster greatbows **++ Super-Heavy Auxiliary Detachment (Chaos - Thousand Sons) [23 PL, 445pts] ++** **+ Lord of War +** **Magnus the Red [23 PL, 445pts]:** **++ Battalion Detachment +3CP (Chaos - Daemons) [25 PL, 381pts] **+ HQ +** **Changecaster [4 PL, 78pts]** **Fluxmaster [5 PL, 99pts]** **+ Troops +** **Horrors [8 PL, 140pts]:** 20x Pink Horror **Horrors [4 PL, 32pts]:** Blue Horror, 9x Pair of Brimstone Horrors **Horrors [4 PL, 32pts]:** Blue Horror, 9x Pair of Brimstone Horrors **++ Total: [114 PL, 2000pts] ++** I might end up substituting certain units for more fun ones but this is a good base for a competitive list? Any advice on where to get Tzaangors?

1) The app BattleScribe is completely free and (after figuring out how to navigate it) has all of the info needed on units and list building. Favorite app of all time. 2) Yes they are 3) Yes, one of the cheapest units, decent as massive blobs, wrapping up opponents in combat, or even objective holding. Not an auto-take but definitely have their uses 4) The AoS Tzaangors and 40k Tzaangors are the exact same models except for an extra sprue of autoguna/chainswords in the 40k box. The daemons are the same as well. Don #8217;t be afraid to ask opponents about proxying before battle, most everyone will be okay with subtle differences. Just don #8217;t be the proxier in this video: https://youtu.be/1_UXan8lQa4

Competitively? Probably not Guardians are decent as a buffer unit but it #8217;s not worth it IMO to tie them down with a heavy weapon. Dire avengers will be better in pretty much every way. If you really want heavy weapons you can use the Vaul #8217;s support battery or (my personal favorite) fire prisms and other tanks of the sort. If you doing the Wraith type list than you will need some wave serpents, more wraithguard/blade, a spiritseer/wraithseer to support and then possible a wraithlord/warwalker. If you are going with the wraithlord I prefer kitting him out cheaply with cannons, flamers, and ghostglaive. War walkers can be used as heavy weapons platforms basically with dual bright lances for av or other weapons depending on role. However, if you are okay straying away from the Wraith type army then aspect warriors are very powerful. Dark reapers are one of the best units right now, set them in a corner, protect with smaller units (dire avengers or guardians) and blast every to oblivion. Fire dragons are great at av but very fragile. Howling banshees and striking scorpions are your best melee units (besides wraithblades) but once again, very fragile. No matter what you do, you will most likely need a wave serpent or two. I personally love two or three fire prisms all working together (if they all sit still they can each fire the Cannon twice and for only 1 cp you can fire them all at the same target, ignoring range and los effectively, and rerolling hits and wounds. (Amazing combo)). HQ wise, you farseers are some of the best psychers of the game, definitely want at least the one it comes with. Warlock spam is very powerful as well, most all their powers are good (I prefer the single warlocks compared to the conclave but it #8217;s up to you). Autarchs are you only way to get command points back as far as I know and can also fulfill vital roles on the battlefield. Consider getting the Triumvirate of Ynnead as well, Yvraine is another extremely powerful psycher. Feel free to message me about any other questions, hope I provided some insight.

Tzeentch daemons are great but they work best when mixed with thousand sons in my opinion to provide some stronger units. Horrors are great, 9 brimstones with 1 blue (to cast smite without dying) is one of the cheapest smite batteries coming it at only 32 points. Also the best way to fill up a battalion. The changeling is pretty much your best buff hq along with the your heralds. Whether you take chariot, disc or just on foot depends on what you are going to be running it alongside and how many points you have to spare. Flamers are some of the best anti-horde units right now due to their weapons being pistols and you can use them in combat. Exalted flamers can be used in pretty much any role. Screamers are your objective grabbers, somewhat underrated imo. Kairos/LoC are good just overpriced. Other units all have their uses but are not standout units imo. As for allying with thousand sons, rubric marines are very durable and provide good consistent fire if you have the points. SOT is great alpha strike units, but once again, expensive. All daemon engines can be great, I prefer using them as distraction carnifex rather than actual damage dealers, but they can be that as well. Tzaangors are your best melee unit you have available to you (despite how ugly they are). Exalted sorcerers and the like are great support units. TL;DR I suggest allying with thousand sons. Horrors, screamers, flamers, exalted flamers, rubricae, SOT, daemon engines, and exalted sorcerers are all great and will fill vital roles on the battlefield. Also look through r/thousandsons. They have great unit summaries including daemon ones.

As someone who play dark eldar, the best thing about them is that they are fast, don #8217;t bother trying to hide valuable units far away or in cover because somehow dark eldar will get within range with something you forgot about. Dark eldar are literally a glass cannon, very powerful (most everything either wounds on a 4+ on everything or is s8 ap-4 d 3 or 6) use whatever units you like just know to focus fire on a single unit until it is destroyed. Units only get more powerful as the turns go on so I suggest not trying to wait then out by just sitting on objectives. It #8217;s hard to give strategies without knowing his list but I hope this helped.

Not a perfect list but it #8217;s the best I could make from what you have #160; **++ Patrol Detachment (Chaos - Thousand Sons) [30 PL, 521pts] ++** **+ HQ +** **Daemon Prince of Tzeentch [9 PL, 180pts]:** Malefic talon, Wings **+ Troops +** **Rubric Marines [14 PL, 220pts]** . **Aspiring Sorcerer:** Force stave, Inferno Bolt Pistol . **8x Rubric Marine w/ Inferno Boltgun:** 8x Inferno boltgun . **Rubric Marine w/ Soulreaper cannon:** Soulreaper cannon **Tzaangors [4 PL, 70pts]:** 9x Tzaangor w/ Tzaangor Blades . **Twistbray:** Tzaangor blades **+ Fast Attack +** **Tzaangor Enlightened [3 PL, 51pts]:** Aviarch, 2x Enlightened, Fatecaster greatbows **++ Battalion Detachment +3CP (Chaos - Daemons) [64 PL, 1144pts] ++** **+ No Force Org Slot +** **Chaos Allegiance:** Tzeentch **+ HQ +** **Fateskimmer [8 PL, 150pts]** **Kairos Fateweaver [19 PL, 370pts]** **The Changeling [5 PL, 100pts]** **+ Troops +** **Horrors [12 PL, 190pts]:** 10x Blue Horror, 20x Pink Horror **Horrors [4 PL, 32pts]:** 3x Blue Horror, 9x Pair of Brimstone Horrors **Horrors [4 PL, 32pts]:** 3x Blue Horror, 9x Pair of Brimstone Horrors **+ Elites +** **Flamers [4 PL, 84pts]:** 2x Flamer, Pyrocaster **+ Fast Attack +** **Screamers [4 PL, 93pts]:** 3x Screamer **Screamers [4 PL, 93pts]:** 3x Screamer **++ Supreme Command Detachment +1CP (Chaos - Thousand Sons) [18 PL, 312pts] ++** **+ HQ +** **Sorcerer [6 PL, 104pts]:** Force sword, Inferno Bolt Pistol **Sorcerer [6 PL, 104pts]:** Force sword, Inferno Bolt Pistol **Sorcerer [6 PL, 104pts]:** Force sword, Inferno Bolt Pistol Total: [112 PL, 1997pts] I don #8217;t love Kairos or LoC but you need some sort of big threat imo. You don #8217;t have to include the flamers/screamers in the list if you #8217;d like and instead summon them in but I just put them there for point values. Basically the big block of pink horrors is that big so as to bump up weapons to assault 3, the blues are just there to kill of first as a buffer. The brimstone/blue groups are just cheap objective holders/smite batteries/detachment fillers, nothing special but make sure to cast smite with your blues so a brimstone doesn #8217;t die every time. The sorcerers work best as buff units, not sure if you need 3 of them but it gives you an extra command point so might as well. The daemon prince works well in the midst of the fight buffing and attacking everything around him. In the future tho I would get more tzaangors so they can become your threat instead of Kairos (nice but not very competitive for the points), a block of 30 tzaangors supported by a shaman can do some crazy damage. Rubricae are great for durable units which you don #8217;t have a lot of. Other than that just play a lot of games against different armies to figure out what you like and what works best for your play style Let us know what you decide and how it goes :)

I #8217;m sure you #8217;ve heard countless people tell you to pick what you like aesthetically so I will spare telling you again. Eldar - one of my personal favorite armies, a wraith army is completely viable. I absolutely love all things wraith. Wraithguard with d-scythes can absolutely destroy most infantry and basically anything else within range. I #8217;ve dropped down 10 wraithguard with d-cannons and dealt 23 wounds to an imperial knight (not statistically correct but possible). Wraithblades are some of the best melee units available, I prefer their shooty cousins but it #8217;s fun to switch it up. Wraithlords are great as either cheap dual flamers/ghostglaive melee units or weapons platforms with a couple bright lances on the shoulders. Spiritseers, warlocks, and farseers all support these units extremely well. I still love my wraithknights as if they were my children but sadly it is hard to justify 500 points for 2 cannons... feel free to pm me for any questions about eldar/allies/strategies Orks- never played them myself but have played against them in 7th edition they were the army that was for people that just wanted to have fun, however, they know are up to a competitive level as well due to the horde meta right now. Before you commit to playing orks make sure you really love the look of them because you will most likely be looking at a lot of them. I can #8217;t offer many strategies other than buy units you like the look of and have fun with them though. Tyranids- definitely a very powerful and versatile army right now. Gaunt spam is a meta list rn but once again, only fun if you want to build and paint and transport and repair and care for that many models. However they also have the ability to run as a more elite army and dish out some nasty mortal wounds. I am partial to eldar but they are all amazing armies.

Well well well, welcome to the universe that will soon take over your life if it hasn #8217;t already. I #8217;m not sure how much you know so I #8217;m going to try and be very basic, I apologize if this is all repeated information. The best advice I can give is to find someone that is either already part of the warhammer universe and can mentor you or someone just starting out as well that can learn with you. Learn about your local game store and go and meet the people, don #8217;t be afraid to talk to someone and ask about their game or advice or if you can just watch them play, as far as I have seen the warhammer community is one of the nicest groups of people. As long as your not rude about it, I promise that people won #8217;t mind helping you out. Aside from that here is my best introduction/army overviews/where to start Warhammer is divided into three groups, imperium (good), chaos (bad), and xenos (aliens (neutral?)) Within each of these groups is many different factions, each of them playing differently from each other Imperium- these are your main protagonists in the stories and the armies consist of: countless chapters of space marines, grey knights, Astra Militarum/imperial guard, adeptus custodes, and other factions and smaller sub factions as well. Most of these armies are going to more elite armies: less models, more versatile, stronger individual models. Chaos - these are your main antagonists in the stories and the armies consist of factions devote to the four chaos gods: World eaters (Khorne), Death Guard (Nurgle), Thousand Sons (Tzeentch ), and Emperor #8217;s children (Slaanesh). As well as other neutral factions and daemons. These armies are somewhat elite normally as well but also include many gruesome monsters and other beings. Xenos - this is pretty much everything else. The main factions are Aeldari, Tyranids, Tau, Orks, and Necrons. These guys have your main horde armies as well as some elite aspects as well. Obviously that was a very brief overview of each faction but from here you have to decide on an army to play. The best way to go about doing this is to look all over the internet at pictures and things like that and decide based on an armies aesthetic first, background second, and playstyle lastly. Many armies have their own Start Collecting boxes which involve normally all the models you will need to build a small fun detachment to build off of. If you are interested in space marines or death guard then they can be found in the Dark Imperium or First Strike boxes You will also need a rule book, your armies codex if they have one (if not their rules can be found in an index instead), and countless other accessories that will accumulate as you begin to truly model and play. I hope I answered some of your questions TL;DR You #8217;re local gamers will be able you much more than anyone on the internet can. Choose an army that you like the look of and dive in headfirst. Please message me if you have any questions about specific armies/strategies/rules questions/embarrassing noob questions/anything else.

Short answer: no, one is not necessarily better than the other. Long answer: games workshop released Warhammer Fantasy and Warhammer 40k around the same time a long time ago. Warhammer fantasy was discontinued in 2013 and age of Sigmar is basically a continuation of it. 40k is more futuristic, space related, big guns, giant tanks, things like that. Sigmar is more fantasy creature and monsters, dragons, ancient fantasy stuff. Gameplay wise they are similar in the aspect of someone new looking at them both but they are different to most actually players just between strategies, typical gameplays, etc. 40k is more popular atm and I suspect it will stay that way but Sigmar is not far behind at all.

Are you thinking more wise? If so then spiritseers would typically lead a wraith army, they also do well in game. Other options for in-game strategy would be warlocks (I prefer desperate than in a conclave) because most of their powers buff wraith units very well (quicken is an amazing power on wraithguard). Avatar of Khaine is expensive but provides a nice little buff, not very accurate fluff wise I suppose. Obviously farseers are your go to universal hq tho. Edit: archons are not great imo, I only use them because they are cheap and can help fill a battalion, their 2++ is nice but other than that they do not have much of a role on the battlefield. Shadowseers are great models imo and a good way to get access to harlequin powers. Never used them myself though so can #8217;t speak to much about them

Eldar can be built somewhat like that: wraithblades, wraithlord, and wraithknight combos. Outside of wraith units you have striking scorpions, howling banshees, storm guardians, and shining spears. Very versatile and fun army to play. If you want to be more competitive back then up with some dark reapers or rangers for some good firepower.

Definitely, the meta army rn is dark reaper spam combined with some fast troops but if you are looking for a fun CC oriented army then you would be looking at things like: Storm guardians - not my favorite unit. Literally just your average guardians but armed with pistols and twin-linked blades. Best part is they are cheap at only 7 points a model. Could be nice combo due to shooting pistols in combat but not real game changers imo. Howling banshees/striking scorpions - both very similar units. Decent point cost (13/14 respectively), pretty fragile, hit decently, pretty fast. Banshees are more defensive and scorpions more offensive but both can be used as tarpit units or melee counters for melee heavy lists. Do decently against MEQs, die very easily to shooting. These are decent overall, fun to play, definitely not game changers though. Wraithblades - extremely fun/scary to play. Very powerful, high point cost, somewhat survivable. Only reason I say they are survivable is due to 3 sounds a piece and a 3+ possible 4++. If plan on hitting MEQs or other infantry units, you might want swords to be able to get an extra attack but axe/shield combo is always justifiable imo. That sweet 4++, +2 strength along with d3 damage can kill just about anything you send it against. I find them best in wave serpents so as to keep them alive until they are needed. Your opponent will target these because they are scary and powerful. These are expensive though, 29 for swords and 39 for axe/shield. Shining spears - I know you don #8217;t like jetbikes but I can #8217;t not mention these guys, I #8217;ll keep it short, but just let me have my fun. These guys can charge in a literally kill pretty much whatever they want. 2 wounds a piece and 2 attacks at s 6 on charge, -4 ap, 2 damage is seriously no joke. One of your best melee units. Wraithlord - your main big boy this edition. Arm him with 2 flamers and a ghostglaive for 131 points of 10 wounds, 3+ save, 8 #8221; movement, 4 attacks, s 9, -4 ap, d6 damage, kill everything around it monster. I am a little biased due to the fact that I just love this model. It can definitely make up its points though and has the capability of being a heavy weapons platform as well. Honestly not to expensive imo as it is basically eldar #8217;s dreadnought. Wraithknight - sadly you will not see much of these big(ger) boys on table anytime soon. Clocking in at 452 points it has an impressive 24 wounds but less impressive 3+ 5++. T8 is nice but doesn #8217;t make it invulnerable. S x2, AP -4, 6 damage is great at killing larger models but rarely makes up its points imo. It can fall back and charge/move over infantry models which removes any tarpit threat. It #8217;s hard to not include the signature of big model of eldar but sadly it takes up too many of your precious points imo. HQ- if you are taking aspect warriors then their corresponding Phoenix lord is a nice buff. Warlocks are amazing due to their points and access to 12 powers in total. Autarchs are a nice way to get command points back. Spirit seers are great buffs for wraith units allowing them to reroll 1 #8217;s. Farseers are you main HQ and give some great psychic support for not too many points. Avatar of Khaine is somewhat hard to justify for his points but really fun to play imo, he also allows retooling of charge ranges within 12 inches. If you want one of the best psychers in the game then you can take eldrad as well. Outside of melee units, dark reapers and rangers are still nearly auto includes even in a melee list simply to provide needed firepower from the back line or any objective you are camping. Wave serpents obviously are you only transport option so should consider a couple at least to move around your most important units. 3x fire prisms is a deadly combo with their strategem and special rules. Hemlocks are nice (honestly a psycher flyer is just badass imo). Craftworld attribute - Alaitoc is pretty useless considering you want to be within 12 inches. Biel-tan as well considering you won #8217;t have many Shuriken weapons. Iyanden is decent but you have better options. Saim-Hann is definitely nice being able to reroll charges. Ulthw #233; gives a little more durability and should be considered. The only other thing you might consider is running an ynnari detachment. FAQ definitely needed them allowing only 1 of each choice and not on your opponents turn but a max unit of reapers firing twice, a melee unit killing one group only to automatically charge into the next, some of your faster units moving double up the field are all helpful. Ynnari also gives access to any of the three characters (which all can hold their own) and Drukhari/harlequins. Drukhari might completely change with the release of their codex but wyches are similar to storm guardians but faster and a little more fragile. Incubi are really cool and hit decently hard. Harlequin troops are very fast and can provide some very powerful melee attacks.

Dark eldar wise you basically just want them for blaster spam. Either MSU of kabalites in venoms (4 rifles, and 1 blaster + double cannon venom=145 points) or blasterborn (true born w/ 4 blasters and 1 rifle+ double cannon venom= 210) a few of those will deal out some major damage but make sure you have some sort of distraction carnifex (big scary defensive model that the enemy will dump shots into and focus on for hopefully multiple turn) a sword+shield wraithknight could definitely do the trick. So now your looking at a big wraithknight with some psychic support swinging at everything in range, probably 2 squads of d-scythe wraithguard in wave serpents or webway striking into the battlefield and absolutely raping everything in sight, a few squads of blaster boys to pop any vehicles/multi-wound models. Throw in a couple razor wings for more firepower or even a hemlock for some fun flying psychic shenanigans (not great this edition but definitely fun). You could consider kabalites in a raider with 9 rifles and 1 cannon. Within 12 inches these guys are throwing 24 shots hitting on 3+ and wounding on 4s always (consider shooting at high toughness targets with these guys), these aren #8217;t great against hordes as their special rule is actually worse then just strength 4. I #8217;ve had these guys take down Guilliman single-handedly before (not likely but possible). One of my favorite eldar combos is 3 fire prisms. Put 2 in heavy cover in the back corners and the other somewhat in the open so it can see targets. As long as they move less then half distance and can see each other you can fire 6 shots of your choice at a single target rerolling hits and wounds for 1 cp (linked fire + special rule). Also remember that there is a big FAQ soon and Drukhari will get a codex soon so everything I said might change.

The number of attacks a model has is solely for close combat (fight phase). In the shooting phase you can shoot as many weapons as you like at as many shots as each has (assault 2=2 shots (some exceptions apply)). In the fight phase a model gets a certain number of attacks that it can split among however many weapons it wants, if it has 2 attacks and 34 weapons then it only gets to hit twice with one or once with one and once with another. If it has 34 attacks and 2 weapons it can divide those attacks up or use one weapon for all. I #8217;m not sure the exact model your speaking of so I can #8217;t clarify that but I hope I helped, let me know if you have any questions.

It #8217;s all about intent, most likely they: 1. Don #8217;t know the rules very well 2. Don #8217;t care to learn the rules 3. Played with certain house rules for so long that they forget they aren #8217;t the real rules The only way to know is to call them out, not in a rude way, just ask them #8220;shouldn #8217;t it be ..... #8221; or #8220;why are you able to ... #8221; if they give you some bullshitty answer then politely ask for them to show in the rule book/codex. They most likely will not refuse but pull some lame excuse about just wanting to play the game/not owning the codex or rulebook/try to turn the situation back on you by complaining you #8217;re a rule stickler and everybody else is more friendly. At this point I would just start packing up my models and thank him for the game. If you are friendly wit the manager then explain the situation but I disagree with the other comments about going straight to the manager because they most likely just ignorant.

Professions are all pretty useless until they reach level 25. Then they become expensive and useless. /s Basically most tasks you complete reward specific xp, everything else is negligible/worthless. Once a profession reaches 25 (its max level) you can begin masterworking that specific profession. The ingredients are incredibly expensive but can yield some profit. They are no longer bis for any class but can still hold their own. Professions are a nice thing to do in the background but ultimately it #8217;s better to focus on pretty much every other aspect of the game if you are still learning/it #8217;s your first play through.

Aeldari? Seems like one of the few not represented armies

No one army is better against other armies, if everyone is playing as meta as possible then they can hold their own, if you play somewhat friendly then any army can hold their own obviously. Playing aeldari is similar to space marines, their are multiple different armies inside and different factions within. I have a personal bias towards drukhari but any of them can be good with craft worlds standing slightly above the others. Drukhari are the ultimate glass cannons, very powerful, lots of shots, lots of poison, lots of darklight (s8 ap -4 d6 damage). But did very easily if left in the open. Harlequins I don #8217;t have much experience with but are extremely fast, have pistol and melee options with less ranged attacks. Work great as a little splash in an army. I recommend experimenting with some troupes in any army you take. Craftworld eldar are the largest and most diverse faction. Bikes are no longer meta but very fun to play imo (i miss 7th edition bike/wraith knight spam). Wraith units are very viable against any army (sadly it #8217;s not worth the points to take wraithknights anymore) I #8217;m sure you #8217;ve heard of dark reaper/ranger spam, personally really boring imo but does a lot of damage. Tldr; everything can be used but if I had to pick craftworld is the strongest and dark reapers the strongest among them. Let me know if you have any questions and I will try my best to answer them

Honestly wraith units are very elite and won #8217;t work well in a 500 point list, they work best with some type of cannon fodder or distraction carnifax (big unit to draw fire) if you really want to start with them you can use something like this Created with BattleScribe (https://battlescribe.net) ++ Unbound Army (Faction) (Aeldari - Craftworlds) [25 PL, 488pts] ++ + No Force Org Slot + Craftworld Attribute: None (Mixed Detachment) + HQ + Warlock [2 PL, 55pts]: 5. Quicken/Restrain, 6: Seer of the Shifting Vector, Craftworlds Warlord, Shuriken Pistol, Witchblade + Troops + Dire Avengers [3 PL, 64pts] . 4x Dire Avenger: 4x Avenger Shuriken Catapult . Dire Avenger Exarch: Two Avenger Shuriken Catapults + Elites + Wraithguard [11 PL, 225pts]: D-scythe, 5x Wraithguard + Dedicated Transport + Wave Serpent [9 PL, 144pts]: Shuriken Cannon, Spirit Stones, Twin Shuriken Cannon ++ Total: [25 PL, 488pts] That is a decent starting point, just throw everything but the dire avengers in the wave serpent and spend a cp to deep strike them onto an objective if needed. Use quicken on the warlock to move flamers into range or if you decide on cannons then pick another fun spell.
That would be a better approach imo, can #8217;t go wrong with farseers, warlocks, dire avengers, rangers, guardians, or even some stranger units like shining spears or swooping hawks
